div1.p: Bridges provides the official military record of Roger Ames' work in Cuba.

div1.head: Letter from C.H. Bridges to Jessie Daniel Ames, November 19, 1929
div1.opener:
C O P Y
AG 201 Ames, Roger Post
(11-18-29)
November 19, 1929
Mrs. Roger Post Ames,
Commission on Interracial Cooperation,
409 Palmer Building,
Atlanta, Georgia.
Dear Madam:
div1.p:
In compliance with the request contained in your
letter of October 25, 1929, you are furnished the following
information concerning your husband, the late Major Roger Post
Ames:- He was sent to Havana, where he remained from April 25,
1899, to November, 1901. As it was known that he had had exper-
ience in the diagnosis and treatment of yellow fever, his services
in Cuba were much in demand in the care of cases of this disease,
especially during the year 1900, when yellow fever was epidemic
in Havana and the neighboring town of Marianao.

Regarding his connection with the work of the Yellow
Fever Board, at the head of which was Major Walter Reed, the
records show that he was on duty at Camp Lazear, the experimental
camp established by the Board, from the date of its establishment,
November 20, 1900, until February 28, 1901, on which date the
camp was discontinued.

He resided at the camp and visited the patients who
became ill of experimental yellow fever and who were immediately
transferred from the camp to the yellow fever ward at Camp Colum-
bia Hospital, a distance of about a mile. His work at the camp
was both administrative in his being in charge of the soldiers
and civilians (Spaniards) at the camp, and professional in that
he looked after those who were taken sick. He performed his
duties with skill, attention and fidelity.

While there is no record of any publication filed in
his name relative to the progress and science of medicine, it is
evident that during his service in Cuba he contributed much to
the comfort, well-being and safety of his patients. His record
in the Army is one that his family can view with legitimate pride
and satisfaction.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, C. H. Bridges (S)
Major General,
The Adjutant General.
